metadata.description: First-time user, cautious, confused, hesitant. Evaluating onboarding clarity and UX guidance.

test_results.title: Kakao OAuth login from union landing page

findings.summary: Login page provides adequate guidance for first-time users
findings.detail: LoginForm (app/_lib/widgets/landing/LoginForm.tsx:138-143) displays helpful guidance text: '처음 오셨나요? 소셜 로그인 후 간단한 정보 입력으로 조합원 등록을 완료하실 수 있습니다.' This properly sets expectations for a newbie. The login button text '카카오로 시작하기' (Start with Kakao) is clear and action-oriented.
findings.expected: Clear guidance for first-time users
findings.actual: Adequate guidance text present

findings.summary: Naver login button is commented out but handler exists, potentially confusing if uncommented
findings.detail: In LoginForm.tsx:93-111, the Naver login button is entirely commented out with a JSX block comment. However, the handler _handleNaverLogin (prefixed with underscore) exists at line 39-51. For newbie users who may have Naver accounts but not Kakao, this limits login options. Currently only Kakao is available, which is fine from a UX perspective but could be confusing if users are told about Naver login elsewhere.
findings.expected: All advertised login methods are available
findings.actual: Only Kakao login is active; Naver is commented out
findings.recommendation: Ensure documentation and user-facing materials only reference Kakao login until Naver is re-enabled

findings.summary: Naver login button is disabled (commented out) with no user-facing explanation
findings.detail: The Naver login button is completely commented out in LoginForm.tsx:93-111. A newbie who only has a Naver account (common in Korea) would have no way to log in and no explanation about why Naver is unavailable. There is no message indicating alternative login options or explaining that Naver login is temporarily unavailable.
findings.expected: Either Naver login works or a message explains its absence
findings.actual: Naver login silently absent with no user guidance
findings.recommendation: Add a small note if Naver login is temporarily disabled, or remove all references to Naver login from the codebase to avoid confusion

test_results.title: User registration via RegisterModal after first login

findings.summary: Step-by-step wizard design is excellent for newbie users
findings.detail: RegisterModal uses a 'digital accessibility friendly' single-field-at-a-time wizard approach (RegisterModal.tsx:328 comment: '디지털 약자 친화적인 한 번에 하나의 입력 필드만 보여주는 방식'). This is ideal for the newbie persona. Each step has a label, placeholder, description, and subDescription for additional context. Progress indicator (dot-based) shows current position. 12 total steps including confirmation.
findings.expected: Registration flow should be beginner-friendly
findings.actual: Excellent step-by-step wizard design with contextual help

findings.summary: Progress dots are visually identical circles with no labels — a newbie cannot tell which step they are on or what comes next
findings.detail: The progress indicator (RegisterModal.tsx:1296-1309) shows up to 12 small dots (totalSteps = STEPS.length + 1). At 3px radius on mobile, these dots are tiny and provide no semantic meaning. The text '5 / 12 최종 확인' helps somewhat but does not name the current step or remaining steps. For a first-time user navigating a complex registration with property types, addresses, dong/ho, the cognitive load is high without knowing what's ahead.
findings.expected: Progress indicator should communicate what step the user is on and what remains
findings.actual: 12 anonymous dots with only a numeric counter
findings.recommendation: Consider showing step name labels (e.g., '이름 > 생년월일 > 전화번호 > ...') or at minimum a section-based progress (e.g., '기본정보 > 물건지 > 거주지 > 확인')

findings.summary: RegisterModal auto-opens with no prior explanation about what will happen
findings.detail: In LandingPage.tsx:110-117, when a user completes OAuth (authUser exists but user does not), RegisterModal auto-opens after a 100ms delay. A newbie who just clicked 'Start with Kakao' and returned from the OAuth flow suddenly sees a full-screen modal titled '조합원 등록' with no preamble explaining: (1) why this is appearing, (2) what information they will need to prepare, (3) how long it will take. The abrupt transition may confuse or alarm a cautious first-time user.
findings.expected: User understands why registration modal appears and what to expect
findings.actual: Modal appears abruptly with no introductory context or preparation guidance
findings.recommendation: Add a brief welcome/introduction step before the first input field (e.g., '환영합니다! 조합원 등록을 위해 몇 가지 정보를 입력해 주세요. 등기부등본이나 소유권 관련 서류를 준비해 주시면 더 빠르게 진행됩니다.')

findings.summary: Newbie may not understand '물건지' (property subject to rights) terminology
findings.detail: The term '물건지' is used throughout the registration flow (steps 3-8) but is a legal/real estate term that many ordinary users may not understand. The subDescription at step 3 says '등기부등본상 주소를 입력해주세요' which adds another unfamiliar term. A first-time user from a general apartment context may be confused. The label '물건지 주소' (RegisterModal.tsx:189) gives the placeholder '서울특별시 강남구 테헤란로 123' which helps, but the term itself remains unclear.
findings.expected: Labels should use language accessible to non-experts
findings.actual: Legal terminology '물건지' used without plain-language explanation
findings.recommendation: Add a tooltip or inline explanation: '물건지란 소유권이 있는 부동산 주소입니다 (예: 내 아파트 주소)'

findings.summary: Property type selection presents 6 options with compact descriptions that may overwhelm a newbie
findings.detail: PROPERTY_TYPE_OPTIONS (RegisterModal.tsx:56-111) shows 6 property types: 아파트, 빌라/다세대, 주상복합, 다가구 주택, 단독주택, 상업용. Each has an icon (emoji), label, description, and example. While descriptions exist, terms like '주상복합' (mixed commercial-residential) or '다가구 주택' (multi-family house) can be confusing for a newbie. However, the example field helps (e.g., '강남 아파트 1206호').
findings.expected: Property type selection should be intuitive for all users
findings.actual: Adequate but could be clearer for non-expert users
findings.recommendation: Consider adding images/icons or a 'not sure? pick the closest match' guidance for users who are uncertain

findings.summary: Floor type (지상/지하) selection step appears without context on why it matters
findings.detail: Step 'property_floor_type' (RegisterModal.tsx:218-226) asks users to select between above-ground and below-ground floors. The description says '지상층 또는 지하층을 선택해주세요' and subDescription says '호수 입력 전 선택이 필요합니다.' A newbie living in a normal apartment may wonder why this matters or may not understand what 'floor type' means in this context. Most newbies live above ground and this step may feel unnecessary.
findings.expected: Each step should clearly communicate its purpose
findings.actual: Floor type step lacks explanation of why it is needed
findings.recommendation: Pre-select '지상' as default and only show this step if ambiguity exists

findings.summary: Add-property confirmation step may confuse newbie who only has one property
findings.detail: Step 'add_property_confirm' (RegisterModal.tsx:238-246) asks '추가 물건지를 입력하시겠습니까?' with subDescription '다물건자인 경우 추가 물건지를 등록할 수 있습니다.' A newbie with only one property may not know what '다물건자' means. However, the flow includes a skip option (handleSkipAddProperty) which mitigates this.
findings.expected: Optional steps should be clearly optional and easy to skip
findings.actual: Step exists with skip option but terminology may be confusing
findings.recommendation: Rephrase to: '다른 소유 부동산이 더 있나요? (없으면 건너뛰기)'

findings.summary: Approval pending modal provides good guidance but no estimated timeline range
findings.detail: ApprovalPendingModal (app/_lib/widgets/modal/ApprovalPendingModal.tsx) is well-designed: (1) Friendly greeting with user name, (2) Clear explanation '관리자가 회원 정보를 확인 중입니다', (3) Promise of notification on completion, (4) Estimated timeline '1~2 영업일 내에 처리', (5) Contact guidance '조합 사무실로 연락해주세요'. The 'Main page' button redirects to root '/'. Overall excellent for a newbie's first post-registration experience.
findings.expected: Clear guidance about what happens after registration
findings.actual: Comprehensive and well-structured guidance

findings.summary: Invite prefill works but user may not notice which fields are pre-filled
findings.detail: When invite data exists, RegisterModal pre-fills name, phone_number, and property_address from the cookie (LandingPage.tsx:159-165, RegisterModal.tsx:424-472). Fields are populated but there is no visual distinction (e.g., highlighted background, 'pre-filled' label) to indicate which fields were auto-filled versus which the user needs to verify. A cautious newbie may re-enter all data unnecessarily or may not notice pre-filled values and accidentally submit incorrect auto-filled data.
findings.expected: Pre-filled fields should be visually distinguishable
findings.actual: Pre-filled fields look identical to user-entered fields
findings.recommendation: Add a subtle visual indicator or info message like '초대 정보에서 자동으로 입력되었습니다. 확인 후 수정해 주세요.'

test_results.title: User re-login after registration (returning user flow)

findings.summary: Returning PENDING_APPROVAL user sees approval modal correctly via UserStatusModal
findings.detail: UserStatusModal.tsx correctly detects userStatus === 'PENDING_APPROVAL' or URL param status=pending and shows ApprovalPendingModal. The auth callback (auth/callback/route.ts:401-403) redirects to '/{slug}?status=pending' for PENDING_APPROVAL users. This flow is clear for a returning newbie who already registered. However, there's no indication on the landing page that they should 'log in again to check status' — the pending modal only appears after successful re-login.
findings.expected: Returning user should understand their current status easily
findings.actual: Status modal appears correctly after login but no pre-login guidance exists

findings.summary: No onboarding guidance after approval — user lands on home page with no tour or help
findings.detail: After a user is approved (user_status=APPROVED), they are redirected to /{slug} (auth/callback/route.ts:405). UnionLayoutContent renders the homepage layout with header, navigation, and content. However, there is NO onboarding tour, welcome message, or guided first-use experience. A newbie who waited 1-2 business days for approval logs in and sees a generic homepage with navigation menus ('조합 소식', '소통방') but no guidance on: (1) what they can do now, (2) where to find notices, (3) how to ask questions, (4) what '내 공시지가 보기' means. The header user menu (UnionHomeHeader.tsx:296-312) has only 2 items: '내 공시지가 보기' and '로그아웃' — neither is a typical onboarding entry point.
findings.expected: First-time approved user should receive onboarding guidance
findings.actual: No onboarding, welcome message, or navigation guidance for first-time approved users
findings.recommendation: Add a one-time welcome banner or guided tour for first-login-after-approval users (e.g., '환영합니다! 조합 소식에서 공지사항을 확인하고, 소통방에서 다른 조합원과 소통해 보세요.')

findings.summary: Navigation menu labels may not be self-explanatory for a newbie
findings.detail: The desktop navigation (UnionHomeHeader.tsx:53-73) has two main groups: '조합 소식' (Union News) with sub-items ['공지사항', '질문 게시판'], and '소통방' (Communication) with sub-items ['조합 정보 공유', '자유 게시판', '협력 업체']. While the labels are in Korean, a newbie may not understand the distinction between '질문 게시판' (Q&A board) and '자유 게시판' (Free board), or what '조합 정보 공유' (Union info sharing) contains versus '공지사항' (Notices). No descriptions or tooltips exist for navigation items.
findings.expected: Navigation should be self-explanatory for new users
findings.actual: Labels exist but distinctions between similar sections are unclear
findings.recommendation: Add brief descriptions in dropdown menus (e.g., '질문 게시판 - 관리자에게 질문하기')

findings.summary: Expired invite token silently falls through to generic new-user flow without error message
findings.detail: In auth/callback/route.ts:303-307, when an admin invite token is expired, the code updates the invite status to EXPIRED and returns null from handleAdminInvitePrefill. Control then falls through to the generic new-user flow (line 248-254) which redirects to the main page where the RegisterModal opens WITHOUT any indication that the invite has expired. A newbie following an expired invite link would see a blank registration form with no pre-filled data and no explanation of why. Similarly for member invites (line 358-363).
findings.expected: User should see clear 'invite link expired' error message
findings.actual: Expired invite silently falls through to generic registration with no notification
findings.recommendation: Redirect to /{slug}?auth_error=invite_expired and show a user-facing error message

findings.summary: Inactive union page provides clear message and home link
findings.detail: UnionLayoutContent.tsx:61-83 handles is_active === false with a clear message: '조합 홈페이지가 비활성화 되었습니다' (Union homepage has been deactivated) and sub-text '해당 조합의 홈페이지가 현재 비활성화 상태입니다. 자세한 내용은 조합에 문의해주세요.' A '홈으로 돌아가기' (Return home) button links to '/'. This is clear and appropriate for a newbie.
findings.expected: Clear message for inactive union
findings.actual: Good user-facing error with guidance

findings.summary: Blocked user modal uses alarming language '허용되지 않은 접근' which may scare a newbie who was blocked by mistake
findings.detail: BlockedUserModal (app/_lib/widgets/common/BlockedUserModal.tsx:28-31) displays '접근이 제한되었습니다' (Access restricted) header and body text '허용되지 않은 접근입니다. 조합 사무실에 문의하세요.' (Unauthorized access. Contact the union office.) For a newbie who was blocked by mistake or due to a data discrepancy, this language is intimidating and does not explain what they should do differently. The block reason is shown if available, and the union phone number is displayed with a clickable tel: link which is helpful.
findings.expected: Blocked user message should be firm but not alarming, especially for potential mistakes
findings.actual: Language is harsh ('허용되지 않은 접근') for a potentially innocent blocked user
findings.recommendation: Soften language to: '현재 계정 접근이 제한되어 있습니다. 문의사항이 있으시면 조합 사무실에 연락해 주세요.'

test_results.title: Notice popup display on first visit

findings.summary: Notice popup has good UX with 24-hour hide option and clear close button
findings.detail: NoticePopup (app/_lib/widgets/notice-popup/NoticePopup.tsx) displays notice content with sanitized HTML, a '24시간 동안 안보기' checkbox, and clear close buttons (both X icon and text '닫기'). The close button has min-w/min-h of 44px for touch targets. The localStorage-based 24-hour hide is well-implemented. Content is XSS-protected via sanitizeHtml(). This is a good experience for a newbie — the popup is informative but not intrusive.
findings.expected: Notice popup should be informative but dismissible
findings.actual: Well-designed popup with clear dismiss options

test_results.title: Error page experience (404, content not found)

findings.summary: Content-not-found pages show error text but no navigation guidance for newbie
findings.detail: Notice detail page (notice/[id]/page.tsx:62-69) shows '공지사항을 찾을 수 없습니다' in red (#D9534F) text centered in a 64-height container, but no back button, no link to the notice list, and no suggestion for what to do next. Free board detail (free-board/[id]/page.tsx:68-75) similarly shows '게시글을 찾을 수 없습니다' with the same pattern. QnA detail follows the same pattern. For a newbie who may have arrived via a shared link or bookmark, being stranded on an error page with no navigation guidance is frustrating.
findings.expected: Error pages should provide navigation guidance (back button, list link)
findings.actual: Error text shown with no navigation options besides browser back
findings.recommendation: Add a '목록으로 돌아가기' button below the error message linking to the respective board list page

findings.summary: Mobile sidebar is well-structured with clear navigation and user info
findings.detail: UnionMobileSidebar (app/_lib/widgets/union/header/UnionMobileSidebar.tsx) uses Radix Sheet component for slide-in sidebar from left. It includes: (1) Union logo and name at top with home link, (2) Collapsible navigation groups with clear expand/collapse indicators, (3) Active route highlighting, (4) User greeting section at bottom with name and '안녕하세요', (5) Account sub-menu with '내 공시지가 보기' and '로그아웃'. Accessible with SheetTitle and SheetDescription (sr-only). The sidebar is 280px wide which is appropriate for mobile.
findings.expected: Mobile sidebar should be intuitive for first-time mobile users
findings.actual: Well-structured sidebar with good UX patterns

findings.summary: User menu only has 2 items — no profile view/edit accessible to regular user
findings.detail: The desktop user dropdown (UnionHomeHeader.tsx:296-312) contains only: '내 공시지가 보기' (View my official land price) and '로그아웃' (Logout). There is no 'My profile', 'Edit my information', 'My posts', or any personal account management. A newbie who wants to verify or update their registered information (name, phone, address) has no way to do so after registration. This is a significant UX gap for a first-time user who may have made a mistake during registration.
findings.expected: User menu should provide access to profile viewing/editing
findings.actual: Only land price viewer and logout; no profile management
findings.recommendation: Add '내 정보 수정' (Edit my info) link to the user menu

findings.summary: Desktop navigation uses hover-triggered dropdowns which may confuse hesitant users
findings.detail: NavigationMenu uses NavigationMenuTrigger with onClick and onPointerDown both prevented (e.preventDefault at lines 213-214). The dropdowns appear via the Radix NavigationMenu hover/focus behavior. A cautious newbie clicking (not hovering) the menu label may not realize the dropdown opens on hover only. However, this is standard Radix NavigationMenu behavior and should work acceptably.
findings.expected: Navigation menus should be discoverable
findings.actual: Standard hover-based dropdown; click is prevented on trigger

findings.summary: Loading states use Skeleton components consistently but no text feedback
findings.detail: UnionLayoutContent.tsx:47-55 shows a large Skeleton (w-full h-[600px]) during union/auth loading. Detail pages (notice, free-board, qna) each show Skeleton (w-full h-[600px]) during content loading. LoginForm shows a spinner with '로그인 중...' text (LoginForm.tsx:115-135). RegisterModal shows loading spinner during submission. While Skeleton is good practice, a newbie may not recognize the grey animated rectangle as a 'loading' indicator. No explicit '로딩 중...' text accompanies the main layout skeleton.
findings.expected: Loading states should be clearly identifiable as loading
findings.actual: Skeleton is used consistently; login shows text feedback but main layout does not
findings.recommendation: Consider adding '페이지 로딩 중...' text below or above the skeleton

findings.summary: Registration validation errors are generic and not field-specific
findings.detail: RegisterModal validation (line 844) generates errors like '{label}은(는) 필수 입력 항목입니다.' (e.g., '이름 (소유자명)은(는) 필수 입력 항목입니다.'). While this works for single-field steps, the final submit validation (line 1018-1033) uses generic messages like '이름, 휴대폰 번호는 필수 입력 항목입니다' without indicating which specific field is missing. For the final confirmation step, the error '개인정보 수집 및 이용에 동의해주세요' (line 1031) is clear. However, auth errors return generic messages: '인증 정보가 없습니다. 다시 로그인해주세요' (line 1036) and '회원가입 중 오류가 발생했습니다. 다시 시도해주세요' (line 1253) which give no guidance on what actually went wrong.
findings.expected: Error messages should be specific and actionable
findings.actual: Step-level validation is decent but submission errors are generic
findings.recommendation: Provide more specific error messages for common failure cases (e.g., network error vs. duplicate user vs. server error)

findings.summary: OAuth error displayed as URL parameter with no user-facing message
findings.detail: Auth callback (auth/callback/route.ts:42-43) redirects to '/{slug}?auth_error=no_code' or '?auth_error=session_error' on OAuth failure. However, there is no code in LandingPage or LoginForm that reads the 'auth_error' URL parameter and displays a user-facing error message. A newbie whose OAuth failed would land back on the landing page with no visible error — they would not know what went wrong or what to do next. The error parameter exists only in the URL bar, which a newbie would not check.
findings.expected: OAuth errors should be displayed to the user
findings.actual: Error codes appended to URL but never read or displayed in the UI
findings.recommendation: Add useSearchParams in LoginForm or LandingPage to detect auth_error and display an appropriate Korean-language error message

findings.summary: Rejection re-application modal requires birth_date as mandatory but original registration does not
findings.detail: ApprovalRejectedModal edit mode (line 153) validates: 'if (!form.birth_date) { setError(생년월일을 입력해주세요.) }' — making birth_date mandatory for re-application. However, in the original RegisterModal, birth_date step has 'required: false' (line 172) with subDescription '입력하지 않아도 진행 가능합니다.' This inconsistency is confusing for a newbie: they were told birth date was optional during registration, but now it's required for re-application after rejection.
findings.expected: Field requirements should be consistent between registration and re-application
findings.actual: birth_date is optional in registration but mandatory in re-application
findings.recommendation: Align birth_date requirement: either make it optional in both flows or required in both

test_results.title: Help and support accessibility for newbie users

findings.summary: No help, FAQ, support, or guidance system exists anywhere in the application for regular users
findings.detail: After thorough code review, there is NO help system, FAQ page, tutorial, tooltip system, chatbot, or user guide anywhere in the application for regular USER role. The only help-related content is: (1) '조합 사무실로 연락해주세요' text in approval/blocked modals, and (2) the landing page note about social login. There are no: (a) Help menu item in navigation, (b) FAQ section, (c) User guide or manual, (d) Contextual help tooltips on complex features, (e) 'How to use' pages, (f) Contact/support page for users. For a Korean apartment union management platform targeting non-tech-savvy property owners (many of whom are elderly), this is a critical UX gap. The target demographic ('디지털 약자' - digitally vulnerable, as mentioned in the code comment at RegisterModal.tsx:328) would particularly benefit from comprehensive help resources.
findings.location: Global — no help system found in codebase
findings.expected: Application should have help/support/FAQ accessible to all users
findings.actual: No help system exists; only phone contact references in error modals
findings.recommendation: Add a help/FAQ section accessible from the navigation menu, including: (1) How to use each feature, (2) Common questions about union membership, (3) Contact information, (4) Video tutorials for key flows

strengths: Step-by-step registration wizard is excellent for digital beginners (single-field-at-a-time design)
Approval pending modal provides comprehensive and reassuring guidance
Mobile sidebar navigation is well-structured with proper accessibility
Loading states use consistent Skeleton patterns
Notice popup has good UX with 24-hour dismiss option
Korean language is natural and appropriate throughout
Error messages in modals use role='alert' for accessibility
BlockedUserModal shows union phone number with clickable tel: link
critical_issues: No help/FAQ/support system for regular users — critical gap for non-tech-savvy target demographic
OAuth errors not displayed to users (auth_error URL param never read in UI)
No onboarding experience after first approval — approved user gets no guidance
Registration modal auto-opens with no introductory explanation
Progress indicator shows 12 anonymous dots — cognitive overload for beginners

cross_references.issue: CRITICAL: useDeleteNotice has no ownership/role guard — any authenticated user can delete any notice via direct mutation call
cross_references.relevance_to_newbie: LOW — Newbie Jamie would not discover unguarded mutation through normal UI usage since delete button is hidden for non-admins. However, this is a security issue that could affect newbie's content (notices they read could be deleted by other users).

cross_references.issue: HIGH: Cascade-delete ordering bug in useDeleteFreeBoard — files/comments deleted before ownership check
cross_references.relevance_to_newbie: MEDIUM — If a newbie deletes their own free board post and the ownership check fails for any reason (stale auth context), orphaned files and comments would be permanently lost. The newbie would not understand why their content partially disappeared.

improvement_priorities.description: Add FAQ/Help section accessible from main navigation for all users
Add welcome/guided tour for first-time approved users
Display auth_error URL parameters as user-facing error messages in Korean
Add welcome/preparation step before registration and improve progress indicator
Add profile view/edit in user menu for post-registration corrections
